We are about to hear a key to a writer's mind.

You can hold a key and just imagine so many different things about it.
A key opens a door or a chest, some hidden space.
Oyeyemi's new book is called ""What Is Not Yours Is Not Yours."" Often enough, her stories wander a little past the edge of realism.
And that style is characteristic of this British author.

ANDRE BRENT(ph) (Overseas Pools): Want to get on the water over here, get ready to take the test.
Almost a year ago, John Garang was killed in a helicopter accident.
He was the charismatic leader of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement, a southern Sudanese rebel group that waged a 21-year civil war against Sudan's central government.
Garang helped broker a peace deal in 2005, just months before his death.
Today, that fragile piece persists, thanks in large part to Garang's successor, Salva Kiir Mayardit.
Mr. Kiir is considered by many to be the military mastermind behind the south's successful campaign.
But since the death of Garang, he has been thrust into the world of politics.
Kiir is the current president of South Sudan and the vice president of Sudan's central government.
That means he must keep peace between north and south, broker a cease-fire with neighboring Uganda's notorious Lords Resistance Army, and try to end the genocide in Sudan's western Darfur region.
He visited Washington this week and met with President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.
I spoke with President Kiir earlier and he says the talks with the Bush administration were productive.
(Sudan): The president was very interested to know how to things are developing in Sudan.
The implementation of the CPA, that is the Comprehensive Peace Agreement we signed on January 9, 2005, in Nairobi.
He also asked about the situation in Darfur, how to bring about the factions that did not sign the agreement to bring them onboard to sign the agreement.
And also how to deploy the U.N.
peacekeeping forces in Darfur.
President Kiir, let me interrupt you and ask whether or not you believe this to be the case.
There are those who have been very critical of the Bush administration in terms of perhaps not doing enough to step in with many who see the situation in Darfur as nothing more than a calamity.
It is their responsibility, the obligation of the international community as they committed themselves to protect the people of Darfur.
U.S.
administration also should really take the lead to see to it that civilians are protected from the different groups that are now active in Darfur.
I want to talk to you about the Peace Agreement.
Many people see it as tentative at best.
You yourself have been a military man for most of your career.
Now you find yourself on the political side forced into it by the untimely death of your predecessor and mentor.
I'm curious whether or not you believe that this can be solved diplomatically?
Although I was a military man, in the army it is the politics that you do.
The difference is that in the world it is politics with bloodshed, and it is politics without bloodshed in diplomacy.
I believe we are doing both.
And so I still believe that the implementation of the CPA needs diplomatic solutions and not anything else.

There is concern that, in the end, because the north is militarily stronger, that they will in fact have the upper hand, if you will, to the south region who holds oil, agriculture, minerals, et cetera for those that don't know the region.
How can you safeguard the idea that people from the outside may see that as problematic?
Well, I don't think that the north will resort to military options, because they know that it will not be the best solution for them.
The only best solution to all of us is the implementation of the CPA.
We have been fighting for 21 years and we have seen the bitterness of the war.
None of us would be really in a position to think of going back to war again.
Because Sudan, as a nation, is threatened; it can collapse because there are so many problems.
There is war in Darfur, and there is war in eastern Sudan.
And if the war goes back in southern Sudan, I believe the whole Sudan will be thrown into flames and that may mean disintegration.
So we need really to save our country from disintegrating to smaller groups, like what happened in Somalia.
How do you do that when you see insurgents from the Lords Resistance Army in Uganda?
We have seen regular attacks on the south from that group.
How do you make sure that in fact you can save it from becoming another Somalia, almost anarchy?
Well, the LRA was actually invited to Yuba, to southern Sudan, during the time when we were fighting, and they have no reason to actually come in wage war against the southern Sudanese people.
What we are doing with them is to engage them in peaceful negotiations so that they reach an agreement with the government of Uganda.
Talks are now going on in Yuba, and we are hopeful that they will come out with good results.
And all the citizens that have been displaced can be able now to go back to their homeland.
Should they then not negotiate in good faith and would want to opt for a military solution.
Of course, that would not be good for them.
Yet, Mr. President, you know that there have been concerns that the Sudanese government has been encouraging attacks by the LRA in the south.
Well, that has been of course the case.
They were being encouraged, not the Sudan government of today; it was the Sudan government before the agreement.

When we became partners in the agreement, I don't think that the government of National Unity or the National Congress Party for that matter cannot have any interest in trying to destabilize the government of southern Sudan by using the LRA or any other militias.
These would not be to their interest also.
We are convinced that we will work together so that we bring peace to northern Uganda and automatically to southern Sudan.
If you are used to war, if you've been fighting for 20-plus years, how do you change the mindset of people that there is a better way?

These people you can of course change their minds by introducing any development projects in the area, because if they don't see any change in the situation they will still stick to their guns and many things can happen.
But otherwise, people need the development.
If this thing starts (unintelligible), I think everybody will then see the peace dividends and will not like to go back to war.

The agreement is very clear.
In the (unintelligible) protocol it is stated that the unity of Sudan has be given the chance, and it is the priority that we are now working for.

We have the interim period of six years, after which southern Sudanese will be allowed to go for a referendum where they will now decide to vote either for independence or for unity to confirm the unity.
This depends on the developmental projects that will be carried out by the Government of National of Unity in the south to make the unity attractive, and this is what people are waiting for.

Should the government in the north, that is the Government of National of Unity, convince the people of southern Sudan that we have chances of building our lives together and staying together as citizens of one country, I believe southerners will vote of unity.

As we noted, from north to south you have resources versus military.
From north to south you have a predominantly Muslim and Arab community versus a predominantly Christian society.
When you look at these things - in order to bring unison, in order to bring people coming together, can you do this without outside intervention and outside help?
If not, talk to me specifically about what you want the United States to do?
Well, I already made it very clear to the administration of the United States that whatever resources that we have are not enough to build the south and all other war-effected areas.

So I ask for more assistance that we can be assisted so that we make developments in all of these areas that were effected by the war, and so that the people of these areas also feel that they are part of the country and that there is a change of heart from the central government that has been fighting with them.
This is something that we are working for.
As for other religions, we really don't take it (unintelligible) as a major problem, because we have both Christians and Muslims in southern Sudan.
And we always talk about suppression of religion from a state.
Anybody that uses their religion for political reasons, as a political weapon, this thing is rejected by the (unintelligible) and we'll never accept that thing.
But as long as the religions are given freedom, they can exercise their own faith without any interference or by anybody.
These are our policies.
So I don't think that there is any conflict in that.
